questions.question: What is the primary function of the World Trade Organization (WTO)?
options: To regulate international trade and resolve trade disputes
To provide financial assistance to developing countries
To promote economic development through infrastructure projects
To foster cultural exchange between nations
questions.answer: To regulate international trade and resolve trade disputes

questions.question: What is a key difference between a multinational company (MNC) and a transnational company (TNC)?
options: MNCs have a centralized management structure, while TNCs have a decentralized structure.
MNCs focus on global integration, while TNCs prioritize local responsiveness.
MNCs primarily operate in developed countries, while TNCs focus on emerging markets.
MNCs are publicly traded, while TNCs are privately held.
questions.answer: MNCs focus on global integration, while TNCs prioritize local responsiveness.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of the International Reserve?
options: Special Drawing Rights (SDRs)
Reserve Position in the IMF
Money Market Instruments
Monetary Gold
questions.answer: Money Market Instruments

questions.question: What does LIBOR stand for?
options: London Interbank Offered Rate
Liberalization of Interest Bearing Obligations and Regulations
Liquidity and Investment Benchmark for Overseas Remittances
Legal and Institutional Basis for Offshore Refinancing
questions.answer: London Interbank Offered Rate

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Foreign Trade Policy (FTP) in India?
options: To promote domestic consumption of goods and services
To restrict foreign investment in strategic sectors
To regulate cross-border movement of labor
To enhance India's international trade competitiveness
questions.answer: To enhance India's international trade competitiveness

questions.question: What is dumping in international trade?
options: Selling goods in a foreign market at a price below the cost of production
Exporting goods that are prohibited in the domestic market
Imposing high tariffs on imported goods to protect domestic industries
Providing subsidies to domestic producers to gain an unfair advantage
questions.answer: Selling goods in a foreign market at a price below the cost of production

questions.question: What is the role of the International Finance Corporation (IFC)?
options: To provide loans and grants to governments for infrastructure projects
To promote private sector investment in developing countries
To regulate international currency exchange rates
To monitor global financial markets and prevent systemic risks
questions.answer: To promote private sector investment in developing countries

questions.question: What is the difference between Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) and Foreign Portfolio Investment (FPI)?
options: FDI involves controlling ownership in a foreign company, while FPI is a passive investment.
FDI is a short-term investment, while FPI is a long-term investment.
FDI is primarily focused on developed countries, while FPI targets emerging markets.
FDI is regulated by the World Bank, while FPI is overseen by the IMF.
questions.answer: FDI involves controlling ownership in a foreign company, while FPI is a passive investment.

questions.question: What is a key function of a credit rating agency?
options: To provide financial advice to corporations on capital structure
To assess the creditworthiness of borrowers and issue ratings
To regulate the operations of commercial banks and financial institutions
To guarantee the repayment of loans and bonds
questions.answer: To assess the creditworthiness of borrowers and issue ratings

questions.question: What is the purpose of a letter of credit (LC) in international trade?
options: To provide a guarantee of payment from the buyer to the seller
To finance the transportation of goods between countries
To insure against losses or damages during shipment
To resolve trade disputes between importers and exporters
questions.answer: To provide a guarantee of payment from the buyer to the seller

questions.question: What is the significance of the Bretton Woods Agreement?
options: It established the World Trade Organization (WTO).
It led to the creation of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank.
It introduced the concept of floating exchange rates.
It imposed strict regulations on international capital flows.
questions.answer: It led to the creation of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank.

questions.question: What is a Special Drawing Right (SDR)?
options: An international reserve asset created by the IMF
A type of bond issued by developing countries
A currency used for transactions between central banks
A form of foreign aid provided by developed countries
questions.answer: An international reserve asset created by the IMF

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Export Promotion Council (EPC) in India?
options: To regulate imports and protect domestic industries
To provide financial assistance to exporters
To promote Indian exports and facilitate trade
To negotiate trade agreements with other countries
questions.answer: To promote Indian exports and facilitate trade

questions.question: What is the role of the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI)?
options: To regulate the banking sector and control money supply
To oversee and develop the Indian capital market
To promote foreign investment in infrastructure projects
To provide insurance coverage for export shipments
questions.answer: To oversee and develop the Indian capital market

questions.question: What is the difference between a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) and a Customs Union?
options: FTAs eliminate tariffs between member countries, while customs unions also have a common external tariff.
FTAs involve free movement of labor, while customs unions do not.
FTAs are limited to goods, while customs unions also cover services.
FTAs are regional agreements, while customs unions are global agreements.
questions.answer: FTAs eliminate tariffs between member countries, while customs unions also have a common external tariff.

questions.question: What is the impact of globalization on businesses?
options: Increased competition, access to new markets, and technological advancements
Reduced competition, higher trade barriers, and economic isolation
Greater government control, nationalization of industries, and protectionist policies
Slower economic growth, higher unemployment, and reduced consumer spending
questions.answer: Increased competition, access to new markets, and technological advancements

questions.question: What is the significance of a foreign exchange rate?
options: It determines the value of one currency in relation to another.
It sets the interest rates charged on international loans.
It regulates the flow of goods and services between countries.
It determines the balance of payments between nations.
questions.answer: It determines the value of one currency in relation to another.

questions.question: What is a key function of the International Monetary Fund (IMF)?
options: To promote free trade and resolve trade disputes
To provide financial assistance to countries facing balance of payments difficulties
To regulate international banking and financial institutions
To enforce environmental regulations on multinational corporations
questions.answer: To provide financial assistance to countries facing balance of payments difficulties

questions.question: What is a foreign exchange risk?
options: The risk of loss due to fluctuations in exchange rates
The risk of political instability in a foreign country
The risk of non-payment by a foreign buyer
The risk of damage or loss of goods during international shipment
questions.answer: The risk of loss due to fluctuations in exchange rates

questions.question: What is a hedging strategy in international finance?
options: A technique to minimize exposure to foreign exchange risk
A method to maximize profits from currency speculation
A strategy to invest in foreign stock markets
A way to reduce taxes on international transactions
questions.answer: A technique to minimize exposure to foreign exchange risk

questions.question: What is a key difference between a spot exchange rate and a forward exchange rate?
options: Spot rates are for immediate delivery, while forward rates are for future delivery.
Spot rates are fixed, while forward rates fluctuate based on market conditions.
Spot rates are used for large transactions, while forward rates are for small transactions.
Spot rates are determined by central banks, while forward rates are set by commercial banks.
questions.answer: Spot rates are for immediate delivery, while forward rates are for future delivery.

questions.question: What is a foreign exchange market?
options: A physical location where currencies are traded
A global network of banks and financial institutions that facilitate currency exchange
A government agency that regulates exchange rates
An online platform for individuals to trade currencies
questions.answer: A global network of banks and financial institutions that facilitate currency exchange

questions.question: What is the purpose of a balance of payments (BOP) statement?
options: To track the financial performance of a multinational corporation
To record all economic transactions between a country and the rest of the world
To measure the level of economic inequality within a country
To determine the exchange rate between two currencies
questions.answer: To record all economic transactions between a country and the rest of the world

questions.question: What is a current account deficit?
options: When a country imports more goods and services than it exports
When a country's government spending exceeds its revenue
When a country's central bank prints too much money
When a country has a high level of foreign debt
questions.answer: When a country imports more goods and services than it exports

questions.question: What is a key factor that influences foreign exchange rates?
options: Supply and demand for currencies
Government regulations and policies
Political stability and economic performance
All of the above
questions.answer: All of the above

questions.question: What is a foreign exchange derivative?
options: A financial instrument whose value is derived from an underlying asset, such as a currency
A type of bond issued by a foreign government
A loan denominated in a foreign currency
An investment in a foreign stock market
questions.answer: A financial instrument whose value is derived from an underlying asset, such as a currency

questions.question: What is a currency swap?
options: An agreement to exchange currencies at a predetermined rate in the future
A simultaneous purchase and sale of a currency for profit
A loan denominated in one currency and repaid in another
An investment in a basket of foreign currencies
questions.answer: An agreement to exchange currencies at a predetermined rate in the future

questions.question: What is the purpose of a foreign exchange control?
options: To promote free trade and encourage foreign investment
To restrict the flow of currencies in and out of a country
To stabilize exchange rates and prevent currency fluctuations
To facilitate international payments and settlements
questions.answer: To restrict the flow of currencies in and out of a country

questions.question: What is a foreign exchange reserve?
options: A stock of foreign currencies held by a central bank
A fund used to finance international development projects
A type of insurance policy to protect against currency losses
A tax levied on foreign exchange transactions
questions.answer: A stock of foreign currencies held by a central bank

questions.question: What is a key function of a central bank in the foreign exchange market?
options: To set exchange rates and control currency fluctuations
To provide loans to commercial banks in foreign currencies
To regulate the activities of foreign exchange brokers
To intervene in the market to buy or sell currencies
questions.answer: To intervene in the market to buy or sell currencies

questions.question: What is a currency peg?
options: When a country fixes its exchange rate to another currency or a basket of currencies
When a country allows its currency to float freely in the market
When a country adopts a single currency with other nations
When a country uses gold as a backing for its currency
questions.answer: When a country fixes its exchange rate to another currency or a basket of currencies

questions.question: What is a currency crisis?
options: A rapid depreciation of a country's currency
A sudden increase in the value of a country's currency
A shortage of foreign currency reserves
A loss of confidence in a country's banking system
questions.answer: A rapid depreciation of a country's currency

questions.question: What is a key benefit of international trade?
options: It allows countries to specialize in the production of goods and services where they have a comparative advantage.
It reduces competition and protects domestic industries from foreign competition.
It leads to higher prices for consumers and lower wages for workers.
It increases government control over the economy and reduces individual freedom.
questions.answer: It allows countries to specialize in the production of goods and services where they have a comparative advantage.

questions.question: What is a tariff?
options: A tax on imported goods
A subsidy paid to domestic producers
A quota on the quantity of goods that can be imported
A ban on the import of certain goods
questions.answer: A tax on imported goods

questions.question: What is the purpose of a trade agreement?
options: To reduce trade barriers and promote free trade between countries
To increase trade barriers and protect domestic industries from foreign competition
To regulate the flow of labor between countries
To establish a common currency for a group of nations
questions.answer: To reduce trade barriers and promote free trade between countries

questions.question: What is a key challenge of globalization?
options: Increased inequality, job displacement, and environmental degradation
Reduced competition, higher prices, and slower economic growth
Greater government control, nationalization of industries, and protectionist policies
Isolationism, nationalism, and a decline in international cooperation
questions.answer: Increased inequality, job displacement, and environmental degradation

questions.question: What is the role of the World Bank?
options: To provide financial assistance to developing countries for poverty reduction and economic development
To regulate international trade and resolve trade disputes
To manage global currency exchange rates and reserves
To monitor global financial markets and prevent systemic risks
questions.answer: To provide financial assistance to developing countries for poverty reduction and economic development
